items.question: Default adult prescription commonly used is:
items.rationale: NAL-NL2 is widely used for adult fittings.

items.question: Probe tube placement target relative to TM is about:
items.rationale: Place within ~5 mm of the TM for accurate RE measurements.

items.question: REIG equals:
items.rationale: Real-ear insertion gain is aided minus unaided gain.

items.question: Pediatric prescription most used:
items.rationale: DSL v5 is commonly used for pediatric fittings.

items.question: Which inputs are commonly used in verification?
items.rationale: Verify against prescriptive targets for multiple input levels.

items.question: MPO should be set:
items.rationale: Ensure loud sounds are comfortable and safe below UCL.

items.question: Test box OSPL90 measures:
items.rationale: OSPL90 is the 90 dB SPL input maximum output curve.

items.question: Full-On Gain (FOG) is measured:
choices: With all features off and minimum gain
items.rationale: FOG is measured at maximum gain settings per ANSI.

items.question: Equivalent Input Noise (EIN) indicates:
items.rationale: EIN quantifies the device’s internal noise floor.

items.question: After first-fit, soft speech under target on REM. You should:
choices: Increase soft-level gain in affected bands
items.rationale: Adjust gain at soft levels to meet targets and restore audibility.

items.question: The purpose of validation tools (e.g., COSI, APHAB) is to:
items.rationale: Validation gauges patient outcomes in daily life.

items.question: A patient reports loudness discomfort at everyday sounds. First action:
items.rationale: Adjust MPO/high-level gain for loudness comfort; then re-verify.

items.question: For pediatric verification, a critical step is:
items.rationale: RECD customizes coupler-to-ear conversions for accurate pediatric targets.

items.question: A key sign to remake an earmold is:
items.rationale: Leakage causing feedback indicates the mold may need remaking or modification.

items.question: Orientation should cover:
items.rationale: Comprehensive orientation improves success and reduces callbacks.

items.question: To verify directionality you might:
choices: Use a test box or clinic verification with front/back inputs
items.rationale: Acoustic verification can demonstrate directional mic benefit.

items.question: If soft sounds are audible but loud sounds too loud:
items.rationale: Refine compression and MPO to shape loudness growth appropriately.

items.question: A dramatic rise in EIN vs spec suggests:
items.rationale: High EIN indicates internal noise problems—service likely needed.

items.question: If REM probe is too shallow, expected effect:
items.rationale: Shallow probes underestimate HF SPL near the TM.

items.question: Verification confirms:
choices: Device output matches targets in the ear
items.rationale: Verification objectively measures in-ear performance vs targets.

items.question: Validation confirms:
items.rationale: Validation uses outcomes tools to assess real-world benefit.

items.question: For first-time users, adaptation managers can:
choices: Ease into full gain over time
items.rationale: Adaptation gradually increases gain for comfort and acceptance.

items.question: Adult soft/med/loud verification inputs approximate:
items.rationale: Commonly ~55, 65, and 75 dB SPL speech-like signals are used.

items.question: If test box THD is far above spec:
items.rationale: Excessive distortion warrants service after setup rechecks.

items.question: Feedback persists despite manager. First step:
items.rationale: Address physical fit/coupling to reduce leakage, then re-run manager.

items.question: If UCL/LDL not measured, what risk increases?
items.rationale: Without UCL, MPO settings may be unsafe or uncomfortable.

items.question: An important counseling point at delivery:
choices: HAs fix speech in noise fully
items.rationale: Setting expectations and consistent use are critical for success.

items.question: Pediatric safety includes:
choices: Tamperproof battery doors and secure retention
items.rationale: Safety features and retention are important for children.

items.question: Ear impression contraindication:
items.rationale: Avoid impressions when perforation/tubes suspected unless permitted with training.

items.question: Verification of MPO typically uses inputs around:
items.rationale: High-level input checks confirm MPO below UCL.

items.question: If loud sounds are comfortable but soft speech is inaudible:
items.rationale: Boost soft-level gain in relevant bands and re-verify audibility.

items.question: Test box HFA OSPL90 refers to:
items.rationale: HFA OSPL90 averages OSPL90 at specified midband frequencies.

items.question: When verifying features like NR, consider:
choices: Measure with and without feature active
items.rationale: Compare aided responses with features toggled to confirm effect.

items.question: A user with small canal and power needs: choose:
items.rationale: Power BTE with custom mold provides needed output and stability.

items.question: Validation tool matching goals is:
items.rationale: COSI tracks patient’s priority listening goals and outcomes.

items.question: If real-ear shows excessive HF output vs target:
items.rationale: Match targets by adjusting band-specific gain and MPO as needed.

items.question: A receiver replacement is indicated when:
choices: No output and blockage ruled out
items.rationale: If cleaning doesn’t restore output, replace receiver before RMA.

items.question: Primary benefit of REM over simulated fit:
items.rationale: REM captures personal ear acoustics for precise fitting.

items.question: Unexpected feedback after delivery first check:
items.rationale: Check for wax and physical fit issues before DSP changes.

items.question: If the patient struggles only in restaurants, best add-on is:
choices: Remote microphone and counsel on positioning
items.rationale: Remote mics substantially improve SNR in challenging environments.
